lg.l: The shades of night were falling fast,
As through a frontier Frontier. In the Hauraki region, in the north of the North Island. village passed
A man Man. Revealed in the final stanza to be Sir George Grey, former Governor of the colony, who had been elected to Parliament in 1874. who bore in sacrifice,
A blue book with the strange device

“Piako!” Piako. George Grey had successfully disrupted the opening of Parliament in June 1876 by moving a motion against the Government demanding a debate over the sale of the Piako Swamp to a group of land speculators. The anonymous poem was published in the pro-government Evening Argus.
His brow was sad, his eye beneath,
Looked rather wat’ry, and his teeth
Did chatter, as in voice quite weak,
He muttered with a kind of squeak
“Piako!”
In settlers’ houses he saw the light
Of household fires gleam warm and bright,
And then he saw a dismal swamp,
And muttered, as he felt the cramp,
“Piako!”
“Try not the swamp,” the old man said;
[“]The slush’ll reach above your head:
The mud in there is deep and foul!“
He only answered with a howl
“Piako!”
“Oh stay,” a maiden said, “and rest
Thy weary head upon this breast!”
But as her tatooed [sic] lip Tatooed lip. The poem mocks Grey’s reputation for close relations with Māori leaders, and understanding of Māori language and culture. he ‘spied,
He only answered (while he sighed)
“Piako!”
“Beware of floundering in the flax;
Beware of rheumatism’s racks!”
This was the settler’s last farewell.
He only heard a dismal yell,
“Piako!”
At break of day, as out from camp,
The ditchers Ditchers. Labourers employed to drain the Piako swamp to transform it into pastoral land. went into the swamp,
And one or two began to swear,—
A voice cried through the startled air
“Piako!”
A traveller, where they heard the sound,
Up to his neck in mud was found;
His eyes were covered with a glaze,
He muttered in a dreamy haze
“Piako.”
Here in the slush was poor old Grey,

Alive, but nearly drown’d, Nearly drown’d. The Evening Argus had previously described Grey as “an ignus fatuus, whose baleful flickerings have led some twenty way-worn political travellers to flounder hopelessly in the Piako Swamp” (29 June 1876). he lay;
And from his lips, so wan and chill,
He muttered tremblingly and ill,—
“Piako!”
